reviewText: This game is honestly not ready for primetime. I wanted to like it: a classic platformer built around picking up and throwing objects (like Super Mario Bros 2!), with visuals that look like 16-bit+, and a transplant from the defunct XBLIG store which holds a special place in my heart? Awesome.\n\nUnfortunately it's not there yet. The first thing you're greeting by when you get past the start screen is an ugly menu with an enormous font, and about 15 menu options laid out in a two column grid. Even though the menu is a two column grid, you can't push left or right to navigate it, just up and down. The default key bindings are very poor, so I highly recommend you play on a controller. The game features a password system, which sounds like a fun bit of retro nostalgia, but the password system has the letters of the alphabet laid out in a grid... that you can only navigate by pushing up and down. The main menu says Press Start"
date: perhaps a holdover from XBLIG. If you go to exit you get this hideous developer mode prompt asking you if you're sure you want to exit in huge poorly aligned text strings going across the screen.\n\nWhy do I fixate on the menu? Because it's emblematic of how the game feels unfinished. Enter a level and you'll see that the "coin" count (actually is are only one coin per level
recommended: a "hidden" collectible--this could probably be done differently in the UI) is poorly aligned with the heart counter
hoursPlayed: which is vertical like SMB2 to its detriment.\n\nWhen you move between levels
voteText: the map seems to load with the camera facing very far away and then whip across the level with blinding speed to get back to you--this is hard on the eyes and again feels unfinished. This wouldn't be a problem
helpfulPercent: except in a few levels the camera whips by enemies and plays their sounds
votesHelpful: and many of the enemy sounds are very shrill and hard on the ears.\n\nWhen you die
votesTotal: the sound simply stops and the game pauses for a second before fading the foreground to black. The effect looks very strange
votesFunny: the lack of feedback is bad
commentsCount: and it's slow. Consider what happens when you die in classic Super Mario Bros--the little ditty plays
column16: the screen cuts to a lives counter (not applicable here)
column17: but I'm saying it shows how visual and audio feedback is part of how you design a game. That's not present in CotCI DX\n\nText boxes
column18: which appear when you talk to characters in the game
column19: has insufficient spacing between words so when you try to read the text it's difficult to follow.\n\nThere's visible tile seams
column20: as you can see in the screenshot. Some bricks look fine but often the tile textures seem unfinished. The backgrounds are wildly inconsistent: some backgrounds
column21: like the one you can see in the screenshot above with the pig king
column22: have a cool parallax effect. Others are static images but animated. Several levels just have pure black backgrounds.\n\nThe entire game the camera feels a little too zoomed in. An important part of designing a platformer is ensuring the right balance between your character being large enough to see and provide details
column23: but small enough so that jumping and moving feels good. Several levels feature points where it's difficult to see far enough around your character to see what you're doing.\n\nMuch of the level design is oddly boxy. Many of the levels are enormous
column24: particularly those that use the gravity-inverting powerup to send you flying through a vast expanse. Big maps are generally a bad idea when designing a game

column26: platforming or puzzles levels typically are very small and cramped and much of the platforming involves putting low ceilings so that you can't jump near your full height. column29: boost on top of a column

reviewText: Back when Super Mario Bros. 2 came out, there was no such thing as the Mario formula." Sure
date: SMB2 was much different from the previous game
recommended: but SMB was much different from Mario Bros.
hoursPlayed: which was much different from Donkey Kong. We didn't know what to expect from a Mario game
voteText: so we didn't know just how much of an aberration SMB2 would turn out to be. Only later did we realize that SMB2 had strayed pretty far from the blueprint of a traditional Mario game
helpfulPercent: and although some elements of SMB2 turned up in subsequent games
votesHelpful: the Mario series has never really gone back to that well.\n\nCurse of the Crescent Isle does
votesTotal: though. It expands on SMB2's primary mechanics -- riding
commentsCount: and throwing enemies -- by allowing you to hold enemies over your head or under your feet
column16: and also by giving enemies unique powers you can activate. These new wrinkles lend themselves to some interesting puzzles.\n\nAnd the graphics? Completely adorbs."

reviewText: As a huge fan of Super Mario Bros 2/Doki Doki Panic, I love Curse of the Crescent Isle.  Warning: the presentation might be a little rough, but it sticks to its 8-bit NES roots pretty closely.  Audio-wise, it transports you back to the magical days of Subcon with each leap and enemy lift then toss.  The musical tracks are also upbeat and cheerful, matching the game's asthetics perfectly.  Highly recommended for fans of Mario Bros 2, 8-bit games, or supporters or XBLIG developers who have moved to Steam.
voteText: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
This game is a lot like Mario 2/Doki Doki Panic, but instead of picking up enemies to kill other enemies, you pick them up to move around the levels. It took some time to get used to the movement, but it works really, really nicely once you get the hang of it. Now, there are some glitches, but nothing major. I flew off the screen twice, but by picking up the enemy that put me up there I fell back into the world again.

It also has a password system (you get the passwords for each level by opening the pause menu) for easy access to levels you want to play around with.

Two characters to play with, one male and one female. I'm fairly certain they are identical gameplay wise, I didn't notice any difference at least.

All in all, this is a really fun (albeit pretty short) platformer that probably anyone who likes platformers can enjoy. Give it a try, why don't you?

reviewText: TL;DR: Short, but great, Curse of the Crescent Isle DX" is the combination of Monster World IV and Super Mario Bros. 2 you never knew you wanted. It's just not as polished as a true 16-bit classic
date:
though it certainly has as much charm as the real McCoy. Absolutely worth it for $5 or less!
----
----
"Curse of Crescent Isle DX" seems like it came straight from the Genesis/Mega-Drive. With it's closest cousins probably being Monster World IV and Super Mario 2 (with some Alex Kidd and Shantae resemblances to boot)
recommended: and it's theme being a fresh take on some kind of loose Hindu-esque fantasy world
hoursPlayed: it absolutely demands attention from any fan of sidescrollers. Does it have the gameplay chops to back it up?\n\nThere are a few rough edges here or there and it sure is short
voteText: even with added modes like Boss Rush and Speed Run
helpfulPercent: but the answer is "Yes!"\n\nYour main character - you can choose between a guy and a gal - isn't armed with a weapon and doesn't find new items. All they can do initially is jump
votesHelpful: and talk to people (there's not a lot of story in the game
votesTotal: but the dialogue on some of the townspeople is very fun)
votesFunny: but they soon gain the ability to pick up & toss enemies
commentsCount: and then shortly after that gain the ability to "flip" whatever they picked up and ride them. It's very similar to Super Mario Bros. 2
column16: except with added depth in the form of elemental abilities on the enemies you're manhandling.\n\nFor example
column17: one enemy is a frosty element guy - toss him into another enemy (or water) and you'll freeze them in place to use as a platform. Even fireballs
column18: in classic video game logic fashion. There's a few kinds of elements here - drills
column23: they provide good variety throughout. There's also great variety from the level designs
column24: with many areas themed around different gimmicks. Areas with loads of stalactites and stalagmites are designed to be navigated by gravity flippers
column25: for example. There are classic gimmicks like wind blowing sections and ice sections too. It's classic through-and-through. The boss fights are also classically styled
column27: pattern recognition stuff that shouldn't test your patience
column28: but are well made nonetheless.\n\nThe only problem is that the game just lacks some polish. It's not mechanically unpolished at all though. This game *feels* right - the character control is great (which is expected since they can't do a lot). However
column29: the design of some areas tends to break things a bit - you'll throw enemies around and they'll get stuck on collision. Sometimes you won't take damage by slamming into something hurtful from the right angle. Or sometimes you'll get an enemy stuck somewhere and need to restart the current room from the pause menu. It's all tiny things
column30: but they can be annoying nonetheless (especially
column33: for a game with good verticality to its levels
column34: there's no way to look up or down. That's just obnoxious throughout. Blind jumps are always annoying
column35: even if the game is super easy.\n\nOverall
column36: "Curse of Crescent Isle DX" is well-made and fun to play; it's just not perfect. Still
column37: it's soooo cheap! Buy it if you like classic action games and sidescrollers. And lets hope that the developer Adam Mowery here gets to make a "Crescent Isle 2" or something someday that's a little more polished and a whole lot bigger :)"

reviewText: Very fun little nostalgic platformer, albeit a rather short game. Looks great and reminds me personally alot of a Master System game with it's use of colors. Seems mainly inspired by Super Mario 2 along with drawing elements from the Wonder Boy/Monster World series. Fairly easy and simple to complete, which isn't really a bad thing. Some games tend to go a little to far trying to replicate that Nes Hard" type of gameplay. Crescent Isle feels more natural in it's difficulty and more like something that's made to be casually enjoyed.\n\nDoes have a few flaws and bugs at times that can force you to restart the level. Mainly when dealing with losing a monster that you need to complete the level with and not being able to acquire another one. Controls feel very responsive and fluid. The musical tunes are fairly good and catchy. The extra modes and the music player are some nice additional touches. I also like that the game uses a password system
date: which gives it even more of an authentic retro game feel.\n\nYou probably already know whether or not you like these types of games. So if old school style platformers are your thing
recommended: you should get an enjoyable experience from purchasing this."
voteText: true

reviewText:
This is an *amazingly* retro game--if I didn't know better, I'd think it was genuinely made by Sega! XD

It's a wonderful polished Sega-style retro platformer on its own!,
But combine that with the moral/plot depth of the monsters/enemies being your subjects and it being your responsibility to *not* kill them! :D
And with just the simple fact that, not only can you play a girl protagonist, if so, YOU SAVE A MALE DAMSEL IN DISTRESS (IT'S ABOUT TIME, Sheesh!!),

And this is a *great* game; it's definitely going on my top favorites list! :D
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
Not bad for what it is. This a retro platformer that mimics the late NES, early SNES era, but not necessarily the best platformers of that time. There's some interesting and creative mechanics involving the way you interact with enemies - especially that you're not really supposed to kill them - and that actually deserves a significant thumbs up.

The disappointing part of the game is that the controls are not so great. It's been a long time since games like this were in the mainstream, and back then controls like this would have merited a 6/10 rating in a game magazine. You can get around, but everything feels slidey" and a little goofy in places. There are also some unusual quirks to the jumping behavior and I'm not sure if they were intentional or if they were simply a lack of experience with the genre on the part of the developer.

For example
date: in most platformers you have to release the button while standing on something before you can jump again
recommended: but in this game you can release it for a split second while you're airborne and then you'll bounce (into another jump) when you hit the ground. Also
hoursPlayed: if you jump into a ceiling you don't start falling immediately
voteText: but you can hold the jump button and 'slide' against the ceiling until your jump force runs out. Usually these kinds of quirks are bugs
helpfulPercent: but there are several places in this game where they seem almost necessary
votesHelpful:
so... Who knows?

One thing that I DO know is a bug is that the game does not save my graphics settings when it closes. I set it to fullscreen 1080 and when I started it again later it was back to windowed 720.

Anyway
votesTotal: despite these strange quirks and minor issues
votesFunny: it's a decent platformer for $5 and it's fun to play. If it looks interesting to you then go ahead and check it out."

reviewText:
Pros:
+Enjoyable Soundtrack
+Nice to Look at
+Cool Sprites
+Enemies/Bosses are interesting enough

Cons:
-Some very bad level design.
-Puzzles that turn out to not be puzzles at all.
-Screwing up a puzzle and having the only enemy that can help you get through it get stuck in a spot that you cannot reach them forcing you to restart the entire level.

In this case the Cons end up outweighing the Pros. For instance, there is a segment where you are supposed to climb down a vine and avoid fireballs that are being shot at you on each side. But its very easy to figure out you can just fall the entire way without taking any fall damage and just completely skip about half of the level.  Some of the frustrating mechanics are really hard to look past and the level design in this game really holds it back.

reviewText:
Short, very low-poly side-scrolling action platformer.

Although the idea and world is quite charming, to me the graphics were not. Music is repetitive. Level variety is fine. Controls are ok - acceleration is pretty low.
Expect a lot of level restarts - to figure out how to proceed, as you will often get stuck (moved a thing that you would have needed etc), or because the slow acceleration/bad hit detection ♥♥♥♥s you.

Although I did not really *enjoy* playing it, it did hook me to play through, enjoy parts of it, and hunt the achievments. Playing through the entire game a second time only takes an hour (at most).

I got used to the controls, and accepted I had to restart a lot - then it was ok.

(The password input is a pain in the ♥♥♥♥ btw; up & down to go through the alphabet, backspace and enter…)
